Literature Review: Cryo-electron tomography (cryo-ET) has emerged as a powerful technique for visualizing cellular structures in their native environment, providing unprecedented insights into the molecular architecture of cells. This review aims to summarize the recent advancements in cryo-ET, particularly focusing on cryo-focused ion beam-assisted electron tomography (cryo-FIB-ET), and its impact on in situ structural biology and quantitative cell biology. Recent developments in cryo-ET have significantly enhanced the resolution and reliability of structural data obtained from cells. The integration of cryo-FIB-ET has been pivotal in this regard, allowing researchers to prepare high-quality samples by precisely milling away the outer layers of cells to expose internal structures. This method has enabled the visualization of macromolecular complexes and organelles in near-native conditions, which is crucial for understanding their functional roles within the cellular context. One of the key challenges in cryo-ET is the preparation of thin sections of cells that are suitable for imaging. Traditional methods often result in artifacts and loss of structural integrity. However, the use of cryo-FIB has revolutionized sample preparation by enabling the precise removal of material without causing significant damage to the underlying structures. This has led to the generation of high-resolution images that reveal intricate details of cellular components, such as the arrangement of proteins within the nuclear pore complex. The application of cryo-ET in studying viral infections has also shown promising results. For instance, cryo-ET has been used to visualize the entry and replication processes of viruses within host cells, providing valuable insights into the mechanisms of viral infection and potential targets for therapeutic intervention. This approach has been particularly useful in understanding the structural changes that occur during the viral life cycle, which can inform the development of antiviral strategies. In addition to its role in structural biology, cryo-ET has also contributed to the field of quantitative cell biology. By combining cryo-ET with advanced image analysis techniques, researchers can quantify the distribution and interactions of macromolecules within cells. This has led to a better understanding of the dynamic nature of cellular processes, such as the assembly and disassembly of protein complexes. For example, cryo-ET has been used to study the dynamics of the actin cytoskeleton, revealing how it responds to various stimuli and maintains cellular integrity. Another significant advancement in cryo-ET is the development of computational tools for biophysical modeling. These tools allow researchers to integrate structural data from cryo-ET with other experimental techniques, such as X-ray crystallography and NMR spectroscopy, to build comprehensive models of cellular systems. This integrative approach has been instrumental in elucidating the mechanisms of complex biological processes, such as signal transduction and gene regulation. Despite these advancements, several challenges remain in the field of cryo-ET. One of the main limitations is the low throughput of the technique, which restricts the number of samples that can be analyzed. Efforts are underway to develop automated workflows and high-throughput platforms to address this issue. Additionally, the interpretation of cryo-ET data can be challenging due to the complexity of cellular structures and the need for sophisticated image processing algorithms. Ongoing research is focused on improving these algorithms to enhance the accuracy and reliability of structural models derived from cryo-ET data. In conclusion, cryo-ET, particularly when combined with cryo-FIB, has become an indispensable tool in the field of in situ structural biology. Its ability to visualize cellular structures in their native environment has provided new insights into the molecular architecture of cells and has advanced our understanding of structure-function relationships. As the technology continues to evolve, it is expected to play an increasingly important role in uncovering new biology and driving the development of novel therapeutic strategies.
